corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

p.value: Identification of item, date; George Morris Papers; TAM 200; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Donated by Helen Morris in 1997; additional materials were received from Helen Morris in 2001. The accession number associated with this gift is 1997.071.

George Morris (1903-1997) was a long-time labor journalist, principally for the Communist Party USA's newspapers, the <emph render="italic">Daily Worker</emph> (national newspaper) and the <emph render="italic">Western Worker</emph>, their successor titles, and was also at one time head of the Party's National Labor Commission. Born to Jewish parents in the Ukraine, he came to the United States at age sixteen and was one of the founding members of the Communist Party USA.
This collection contains articles by George Morris and others, research materials, speeches and correspondence.

subject.value: Labor unions |z United States |x History |y 20th century.
Labor unions and communism -- United States.

dsc.value: <c id="aspace_ref5" level="file"><did><unittitle>Autobiography, 6 pp., 1981; Speech at Lenin 100th birthday conference; GM article, published in <emph render="italic">Soviet Contemporary</emph>; Letters to PDW editorial board, 1979-1986; Letters to Gus Hall, 1978-1986; Correspondence with Henry Winston, 1973-1986; "Letters" 1968-1984; "Correspondence" 1973-1985; including George Myers, Carl Winter, Mike Zagarell; Testimonial dinners 1970s-1980s; Articles and speeches on trade union matters circa 1979-1986.</unittitle><unitdate>1968-1989</unitdate><container id="aspace_36a4f49d33c882fd3755306e0cdc5866" label="Mixed Materials" type="Box">1</container></did></c><c id="aspace_ref7" level="file"><did><unittitle>Research material for <emph render="italic">American Labor: Which Way</emph> (1961); Harry Bridges letter, May 3 1971; Research material for <emph render="italic">CIA and American Labor: The Subversion of the AFL-CIO's Foreign Policy</emph> (1967); "Historical trade union materials," 1960s-70s. </unittitle><unitdate normal="1960/1979" type="inclusive">1960s-1970s</unitdate><container id="aspace_581dbe8a61abc3ec4b7863ee595f9500" label="Mixed Materials" type="Box">2</container></did></c>
